Legal_Issue: Validity of patent for sildenafil's use in treating erectile dysfunction
Evidence_Assessment: Prior art reviewed, expert testimony evaluated, commercial success considered
Credibility_Factor: Expert opinions differed on obviousness; court credited Pfizer's evidence
Legal_Rule: Patent valid if meets non-obviousness, novelty, and proper claim construction
Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment under statutory patent requirements
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art, expert testimony, commercial success, lack of prior development
Legal_Framework: Statutory patent requirements under Canadian law
Applicant_Challenge: Apotex challenged validity to market generic Viagra
Court_Result: Pfizer's patent upheld; Apotex prohibited from marketing generic until expiry
Defendant_Response: Argued patent was obvious and anticipated by prior art
Remedy_Requested: Declaration of patent invalidity, right to market generic
Legal_Provision: Patent Act, sections on novelty, non-obviousness, utility
Claimant_Status: Apotex as challenger, Pfizer as patent holder
Legal_Provision_Cited: Relevant provisions of the Canadian Patent Act regarding patentability
Applicable_Process: Judicial proceeding under federal patent law
Governing_Rule: Non-obviousness, novelty, and claim construction standards
